events.title: French Surrender: Hassetche Falls to Occupation Without a Fight
events.description: On 8th July, a column was sent to capture Hassetche, the seat of the local Government. in the Bec du Canard. Here the French decided not to fight and the town and fort were occupied without opposition.

events.title: Canadian Forces Advance: Franqueville Secured as Troops Push Toward Caen's Outskirts
events.description: By nightfall, 8th July, 3 Canadian Division had secured Franqueville, while tanks and armoured cars closed in on the western outskirts of Caen. In the centre 59 Division cleared St. Contest and La Bijude, while 3 Division got into the north-east corner of Caen and directed 33 Armoured Brigade to the bridges.

events.title: Second Army Launches Offensive Towards Thury Harcourt, Intensifies Pressure on Multiple Fronts
events.description: During the period roth-18th July, Second Army delivered a series of thrusts, with the primary object to make progress Southwards towards Thury Harcourt: all operations were related to this task and to the maintenance of pressure on as broad a front as possible.

events.title: First U.S. Army Secures Key Terrain Ahead of Major Breakout Operation
events.description: Thus by r8th July First United States Army was in possession of St. L6, and of the ground west of the River Vire which was required for mounting the major break-out assault operation to the south.

events.title: Allied Forces Surge Forward: U.S. Armored Divisions Capture Coutances and Avranches Amid Disarray of Enemy Troops
events.description: While Second British Army was switching its main weight to the Caumont sector, the progress of the break-out operation proceeded apace. On 28th July, 4 and 6 U.S. Armoured Divisions passed through the infantry on the western sector and thrust South towards Coutances. The town was captured in the afternoon and firm contact was established there between VIII and VII Corps. To the SouthEast, troops of VII and XIX Corps had got to within five miles of the main Avranches Caen road. All reports indicated that West of the River Vire to the coast the enemy was completely disorganised. Avranches was taken on 31st July.

events.title: Trade Resumes in Diego Suarez as Aid Shipment Brings Relief Amid British Blockade
events.description: In Diego Suarez area, conditions rapidly returned to normal, although trade was testricted since the British blockade had effectively prevented the replacement of trade goods. Warehouses and shops were empty. With the active co-operation of the Union of South Africa, { 5,000 worth of goods comprising. tea, flour, and cotton piece goods were landed at Diego Suarez on 8th July, 1942. The delivery of these goods created a favourable impression among all sections of local inhabitants, being in strong contrast to the conditions prevailing in the unoccupied area of Madagascar.

events.title: R.A.F. Strikes: 467 Bombers Pave Path to Victory in Caen
events.description: 273. The first of the large scale attacks, using heavy bombers in close support took place at 0430 hours on 8th July. R.A.F. Bomber Command employed 467 bombers to drop 2,562 tons of bombs on positions North of Caen. The British and Canadian troops, held up to the North of the town for so long by the enemy, followed up the bombing with a frontal attack. By nightfall they had entered the streets of Caen. The bombing had therefore succeeded in its object and had opened a way for a break through by the ground forces.

events.title: Allied Forces Launch Massive Air Assault in Operation Goodwood to Support British Advance Near Caen
events.description: 274. The second, and largest, of these operations (Operation Goodwood) took place on 18th July, when the combined weight of the United States Eighth Air Force, Royal Air Force Bomber Command and the Allied Expeditionary Air Force supported an advance by elements of the Second British Army in the Caen area.

events.title: New Threat Emerges: Flying Bombs Target London from the East
events.description: 114. Meanwhile, as early as the 8th July, flying bombs had started to approach London from a new direction, namely from the east. No launching sites were known to exist in Belgium; and after a few weeks it was established that these bombs, which came only at night, were being launched by speciallyequipped He. 111 aircraft operating wholly or mainly from bases in Holland.
